sn1.71:1: At Sāvatthī. Standing to one side, that devata addressed the Blessed One in verse:
sn1.71:2: v.3"Having slain what does one sleep soundly?Having slain what does one not sorrow?What is the one thing, O Gotama,Whose killing you approve?"[n.17] Se, Eejhatvais certainly the correct reading,chetvain Be and Ee1 a normalization. The gloss inSpk,vadhitva,supportsjhatva,and G-Dhp 88–89 has jatva, the Gandharī Prakrit counterpart. See Brough,Gandhari Dharmapada,pp. 164, 65–66.Jhatvais also found in the SS reading of v.94b.
sn1.71:3: v.224"Having slain anger, one sleeps soundly;Having slain anger, one does not sorrow;The killing of anger, O devata,With its poisoned root and honeyed tip:This is the killing the noble ones praise,For having slain that, one does not sorrow."[n.128]Spk: Anger has a poisoned root(visamūla)because it results in suffering. It has a honeyed tip(madhuragga)because pleasure arises when one returns anger with anger, abuse with abuse, or a blow with a blow.
